document.text: This document defines the locked, authoritative structure for all Standard Operating Procedures. Any SOP that violates this constitution is invalid by definition.
The SOP Constitution governs how SOPs are structured, authored, rendered, audited, and enforced.

items: One SOP equals one controlled artifact.
Physical SOPs exist as a single binder section.
Digital SOPs exist as a single controlled file or container.
SOPs must not be fragmented across multiple uncontrolled documents.
Metadata Page
Table of Contents
Production Standard
Operational Reference Standard
Data Reference

document.text: No section may be reordered, merged, or omitted.

items: Appears once and only as the first page.
Contains no procedural content.
Applies authority to all sections of the SOP.
One row per major step.
Steps are ordered and numbered.
Contains no instructions, tolerances, or teaching content.
Provides navigation only.
Mirrors the TOC step order exactly.
Defines what must be done and to what standard.
Assumes participant proficiency.
Contains no teaching or explanatory content.
Mirrors Production steps exactly.
Explains intent, judgment, and error recognition.
Defines what proficiency looks like.
Must not alter execution or introduce alternatives.
Contains authoritative, non-procedural data only.
Contains no steps, sequences, or execution guidance.
May include recipes, specifications, parameters, yields, and reference tables.
May be referenced by any SOP section or other SOPs.
Exists as a separate, dependent artifact.
Bound to the SOP by SOP-ID and step number.
May evolve independently.
Must never contradict the SOP.
Every TOC step maps to exactly one Production step.
Every Production step maps to exactly one Operational Reference step.
No section may introduce new steps.
Step names and order must match verbatim.

document.text: Violation of step binding invalidates the SOP.

items: The canonical source of truth is structured JSON.
Rendered views must be derived mechanically from JSON.
Rendered views must not introduce meaning not present in JSON.
If conflict exists, JSON is authoritative.

document.text: Any SOP not conforming to this constitution is invalid.
Structural changes require an explicit constitutional amendment.

items: TOC must provide explicit drill-down navigation.
Physical SOPs must use page numbers or binder identifiers.
Digital SOPs must use direct links or anchors.
Searching and interpretation are prohibited.
Physical SOPs are never authoritative.
Physical SOPs must be generated mechanically from the canonical JSON.
Every page must display SOP-ID, version, and print date.
Pages must be replaceable individually without reprinting the entire SOP.
Inline data in Production is limited to critical numeric values required at the moment of action.
Safety-critical limits may be duplicated inline.
Visual completion cues may be duplicated inline as data.
Full recipes, specifications, yields, and non-critical ranges must remain in Data Reference.
All inline data must be traceable to a single Data Reference block.
Inline data must be visually marked as rendered reference, not primary authority.
Procedural flow must be expressed only as ordered steps under explicit step headings.
Data may be expressed only as tables or lists.
Tables must not encode execution order.
Tables must not encode conditional logic.
Tables must not replace procedural steps.
If a table implies sequence or decision-making, the SOP is invalid.

document.text: Markdown is the maximum expressive format allowed for digital SOP rendering.

items: Changes to Data Reference content do not alter procedural flow.
Versioning is required when data changes affect execution standards.

document.text: All AI-generated SOPs must comply with this constitution automatically.
This SOP Constitution is locked and in force.
